subject: Psychology
title: Friction as a Tool
description: A fast breakdown of Friction as a Tool for builders.

hook.text: A researcher put candy in an opaque jar instead of a clear one. People ate 71% less. One small friction.

buildup.text: Adding friction â€” extra steps between cue and behavior â€” dramatically reduces unwanted habits.

discovery.text: Log out of social media. Put the remote in a drawer. Move junk food to a high shelf. Friction slows the loop.

twist.text: You don't need to eliminate the bad habit entirely. Just add enough friction to make the automatic response pause.

climax.text: The pause is where choice lives. Friction gives your conscious mind time to intervene before automation takes over.

punchline.text: Make the bad habit slightly harder and it happens far less.

quiz.question: How does adding friction help break bad habits?
options: Extra steps slow the automatic loop and create space for choice
Friction makes habits stronger and more automatic
Adding steps has no effect on habitual behavior
